TRUSTEES ACCEPT
THE THOM CUP
To Be Awarded Annually To
Extemporaneous Speaker
WHEELER IS LAUDED
Given in Memory of Hunt
Thom, Husband of Donor
The Trustees of The Johns Hopkins University have given the
Secretary of the Debating Council
permission to accept a silver loving
cup to be awarded annually to the
winner of an extemporaneous publice speaking contest in memory of
Hunt Thom, husband of Helen
Hunt Thom, authoress of "Johns
Hopkins A Silhouette."
Hunt Thom was a very noted figure in the literary and social history of this country, and with his
wife, the donor of the cup, was a
founder of the Saturday Night
Club, an American literary society
boasting of some of the most cultured minds in the literary world.
Mrs. Thom is quite prominent in
Baltimore society and is a graduate
of Bryn Mawr. Her first literary
work has attained such wide popularity that she is at the present
time devoting herself to another
biography.
Interested In Poetry

Helen Hunt Thom is very interested in poetry and its relation to
oratory, however, inasmuch as such
forensic contests would involve endless difficulties, an extemporaneous
speech contest has been decided
upon.
The Hunt Cup will be awarded
at the third from the last assembly
of the scholastic year which will
be on April 24. At the present
time the plans for the contest are
as follows: Tryouts open to anyone in the University will be held
at various times two or three weeks
before the contest. Five or six men
who prove themselves most capable
will appear at the assembly and will
he judged by seven men prominent
in educational circles. These six
men will be notified a week before
the contest on its general topic.
One hour before the contest each
contestant at ten minute intervals
will be given the specific topic of
the contest, and with one hour's
preparation he will prepare a tenminute oration.

Price 5 Cents

HULLABALOO BOARD
TO MEET REGULARLY
At a meeting of the Board
of Editors of the 1929-30
Hullabaloo yesterday, plans
for the yearbook were discussed. The Board will meet
regularly during the year at
lunch hour in the small dining room adjoining the Levering Hall Cafeteria at which
time the work of the various
editors will be co-ordinated,
since under the plan adopted,
each division of the book is
in the hands of a separate editor working independently of
the other editors.

1929 has been restored to the inmates of the Alumni Dormitory this
year in the blessed and most welcome form of sandwiches and
milk. This service was undertaken by two graduate students of
the ever industrious "E" entry, and
although they may never become
rolling in wealth from their project,
they certainly have the appreciation
ef those whose appetites become
tremendous an hour or so before
midnight. A few early sleepers are
perhaps roused from their slumbers
c calculus and statistics by the reverbrating "sanwche'n milk" at
eleven o'clock, but they are in the
minority and the multitude must be
pleased. Another pair of denizens
have gone into the cigarette business and avoid selling the weeds by
merely giving them away and then
exacting compensation as soon as
the buyer is in some dark corner
where he can receive no assistance.
However, this practice is but the
homework of their accounting class,
and they revel in balancing the
books after the sale of a pack of
cigarettes and spend the remainder
f the evening debiting cash and
crediting coffin nails. To the pressent date their gross profits are approximately seven cents; however,
they are hoping that the Hoover administration will speed up business
a bit in the near future.

TRUSTEES ACCEPT
THE THOM CUP
To Be Awarded Annually To
Extemporaneous Speaker
WHEELER IS LAUDED
Given in Memory of Hunt
Thom, Husband of Donor
The Trustees of The Johns Hopkins University have given the
Secretary of the Debating Council
permission to accept a silver loving
cup to be awarded annually to the
winner of an extemporaneous publice speaking contest in memory of
Hunt Thom, husband of Helen
Hunt Thom, authoress of "Johns
Hopkins A Silhouette."
Hunt Thom was a very noted figure in the literary and social history of this country, and with his
wife, the donor of the cup, was a
founder of the Saturday Night
Club, an American literary society
boasting of some of the most cultured minds in the literary world.
Mrs. Thom is quite prominent in
Baltimore society and is a graduate
of Bryn Mawr. Her first literary
work has attained such wide popularity that she is at the present
time devoting herself to another
biography.
Interested In Poetry

Helen Hunt Thom is very interested in poetry and its relation to
oratory, however, inasmuch as such
forensic contests would involve endless difficulties, an extemporaneous
speech contest has been decided
upon.
The Hunt Cup will be awarded
at the third from the last assembly
of the scholastic year which will
be on April 24. At the present
time the plans for the contest are
as follows: Tryouts open to anyone in the University will be held
at various times two or three weeks
before the contest. Five or six men
who prove themselves most capable
will appear at the assembly and will
he judged by seven men prominent
in educational circles. These six
men will be notified a week before
the contest on its general topic.
One hour before the contest each
contestant at ten minute intervals
will be given the specific topic of
the contest, and with one hour's
preparation he will prepare a tenminute oration.

1929 has been restored to the inmates of the Alumni Dormitory this
year in the blessed and most welcome form of sandwiches and
milk. This service was undertaken by two graduate students of
the ever industrious "E" entry, and
although they may never become
rolling in wealth from their project,
they certainly have the appreciation
ef those whose appetites become
tremendous an hour or so before
midnight. A few early sleepers are
perhaps roused from their slumbers
c calculus and statistics by the reverbrating "sanwche'n milk" at
eleven o'clock, but they are in the
minority and the multitude must be
pleased. Another pair of denizens
have gone into the cigarette business and avoid selling the weeds by
merely giving them away and then
exacting compensation as soon as
the buyer is in some dark corner
where he can receive no assistance.
However, this practice is but the
homework of their accounting class,
and they revel in balancing the
books after the sale of a pack of
cigarettes and spend the remainder
f the evening debiting cash and
crediting coffin nails. To the pressent date their gross profits are approximately seven cents; however,
they are hoping that the Hoover administration will speed up business
a bit in the near future.

An organization meeting of
the 1930 basketball squad
was held yesterday at which
the regulars and newcomers
to the team were present. At
the meeting Purcell, manager
of this season's five, met prospective managers for teams of
succeeding years.
Darley announced practice
for today at 4:15 P. M.
Practice as in previous years
will be held at Carlin's Park
every week day, excluding
Saturday. All interested in
basketball, who didn't appear
yesterday, are urged to attend
this afternoon's session.

On a beautiful pass, from Chalmers to Berger, Maryland forged deep
into the territory of the Jays. The
Jays were fighting like wild cats,
but they were unable to stop these
rushes and aerial attacks of the Terrapins. Two downs later, another
forward pass was attempted successfully and Berger went over for
Maryland's fourth touchdown.
"In the final period Hopkins
stabbed deep into Maryland territory, a gesture which the Terrapins
regarded as extremely impolite. So,
after steady gains through the line,
the Terps tried another long forward pass. Again it was from
Chalmers to Berger and again it
meant six points for Maryland."
In the latter portion of the game,
the Jays came within a short distance of scoring again. Lores Guild
passed to Dip Mills who caught the
pigskin and started for the goal
line. But due to his tired and groggy condition, he was brought down
from the rear by one of the fresh
substitutes of Maryland, on Maryland's 26-yard line.
A few minutes after this, the
game ended with the HopkinsMaryland series standing at 11 victories for each and four games tied.
